Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Catalytic Element-Element Bond Formation: Selectivity and New Catalysis with a Movement Toward Sustainability
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Catalysis Program of the NSF Division of Chemistry supports the research efforts of Professor Rory Waterman of the University of Vermont in the discovery and understanding of catalytic reactions that form bonds between main group elements. Efforts under this award focus on new or improved catalytic reactivity for transformations that form bonds to phosphorus (P). Catalytic dehydrocoupling of phosphines is applied toward the synthesis of novel materials featuring P-P sigma-bonds. Hydrophosphination catalysts, particularly those with primary phosphine substrates, are applied in the preparation of new transition-metal ligands for other catalytic reactions. The unique phosphaalkene synthesis discovered by Prof. Waterman is used in the catalytic preparation of unsaturated phosphorus products. An expansion of alpha elimination catalysis using phosphines as substrates is sought as well. Investigation of these transformations is geared toward expansion to other elements, and provides a venue to train university students as well as outreach opportunities to include high school students in research.

Catalytic syntheses of molecules containing heavier main group elements such as phosphorus or silicon continue to lag substantially behind organic analogs. The disparity in the ease of transformations has slowed the development of main group materials and resulted in high costs for current main group-containing products in terms of both the energy required and the waste produced. These main group-containing molecules are essential components to industrial and consumer products. Some evidence for this comes from the >$13 billion silicone industry alone. Research under this award seeks to provide new feedstocks, synthetic methods, materials, or more efficient syntheses that could improve such enterprises. Phosphorus is a finite resource. The discovery of efficient syntheses may help to preserve phosphorus resources. This research is identified as part of a sustainability chemical portfolio because it is identifying transition metal catalysts that can replace phosphorus in certain applications, to protect our phosphorus-containing resources. Students involved in this research are training to contribute to chemical industry and are also learning to use catalysis for sustainability.

Institution.Name: University of Vermont & State Agricultural College
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & STATE AGRICULTURAL COLLEGE

Performance_Institution.Name: University of Vermont & State Agricultural College

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project sought to identify and better understand more efficient ways in which chemical bonds can be made with elements of high importance like phosphorus, silicon, and arsenic. The approach utilized is metal catalysis, the use of metals as recyclable constituent that facilitates reactions too difficult to proceed otherwise. Most reactions involve the activation of element-hydrogen bonds. There are two main reaction types consider, hydrophosphination (image 1) and dehydrocoupling (image 2). Hydrophosphination, or the addition of a P-H bond across an unsaturated substrate, is a well-known transformation. During this project, a zirconium catalyst that efficiently adds primary phosphines (RPH2) across unsaturated substrates was investigated and reported. There has been a limited amount of investigation with primary phosphine substrates, and the zirconium work has spurred an effort with these substrates from other researchers. The zirconium catalyst was also used with air-stable primary phosphines (most primary phosphines oxidize so readily that they are pyrophoric), an unknown substrate in this reaction. This catalyst was also found to undertake the double hydrophosphination of alkynes, the products of which are important for the development of pharmaceutical agents.

Dehydrocoupling is a reaction that forms chemical bonds between two elements with liberation of hydrogen (H2). Iridium catalysts were explored for silane dehydrocoupling, and the steric and electronic effects that differentiate dehydrocoupling versus competitive redistribution were investigated. Those studies revealed a small dependence on electronic factors with much greater control from the catalyst and substrate steric considerations. In continued investigations of phosphine dehydrocoupling, a unique mechanism was identified, alpha-phosphinidene elimination or the liberation of a low-valent phosphorus fragment. This observation was capitalized upon to prepare organophosphines, molecules important to agriculture, pharmaceuticals, and for materials science.       

Because of the importance of element-hydrogen bond activation for the project goals, catalysis to liberate hydrogen was considered. Those experiments resulted in the identification of two new catalysts for the dehydrogenation of amine-boranes, potential chemical agents to safely store hydrogen as a fuel.

The project provided a venue for the education and professional development of numerous graduate (seeking MS and PhD degrees in chemistry), undergraduate, and high school students, many of whom share credit for results under this award as co-authors on publications or through public presentations on research results.  


Last Modified: 05/26/2016
Modified by: Rory Waterman

The approach utilized is metal catalysis, the use of metals as recyclable constituent that facilitates reactions too difficult to proceed otherwise. Most reactions involve the activation of element-hydrogen bonds. There are two main reaction types consider, hydrophosphination (image 1) and dehydrocoupling (image 2). Hydrophosphination, or the addition of a P-H bond across an unsaturated substrate, is a well-known transformation. This catalyst was also found to undertake the double hydrophosphination of alkynes, the products of which are important for the development of pharmaceutical agents. Dehydrocoupling is a reaction that forms chemical bonds between two elements with liberation of hydrogen (H2). The project provided a venue for the education and professional development of numerous graduate (seeking MS and PhD degrees in chemistry), undergraduate, and high school students, many of whom share credit for results under this award as co-authors on publications or through public presentations on research results.
